Package moulton.scalable.utils

Class MenuComponent

  • java.lang.Object
    • moulton.scalable.utils.MenuComponent
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    AnimatedView, Caption, Clickable, Line, Panel, Polygon, TextHistory, View
    public abstract class MenuComponent
extends java.lang.Object
    The parent class for all components to fit inside of a parent panel. Each component is designed to be scalable. The size of text-based components are scaled by height unless disabled by a parent Panel with Panel.setTextResize(Boolean).
    Author:
    Matthew Moulton

      • parent

      • DEFAULT_ORIGINAL_TEXT_SIZE

        public static final int DEFAULT_ORIGINAL_TEXT_SIZE
        The default value for text_resize_factor.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • text_resize_factor

        protected static int text_resize_factor
        A value that determines the size of text components when resized through getTextVertResize(int). When the container height is equal to this, then the original font size will be used.
        See Also:
        setTextResizeFactor(int)

      • visible

        protected boolean visible
        Visibility of component. Invisible components are uneditable.
        See Also:
        isVisible(), setVisible(boolean)

      • gridPoint

        protected java.awt.Point gridPoint
        The coordinates of this component on parent's grid. Null when this component is not using the panel grid functionality, but rather uses the free-form where the coordinates are derived from x and y.

    • Constructor Detail

      • MenuComponent

        public MenuComponent​(Panel parent,
                     int x,
                     int y)
        Sets the parent panel for this component. Since the component has no String x and y coordinates, it must be reliant upon the panel for determining that information by gridding. Therefore, this constructor will also add this component to the panel's grid.
        Parameters:
        parent - the parent panel for this component. Components on a menu at base-level have a parent panel of MenuManager.menu.
        x - the x coordinate of this component in its parent's grid
        y - the y coordinate of this component in its parent's grid

      • MenuComponent

        public MenuComponent​(Panel parent,
                     java.lang.String x,
                     java.lang.String y)
        Sets the parent panel and coordinate x and y values for this component. They will be solved at run-time by solveString(String, int, int).
        Parameters:
        parent - the parent panel for this component. Components on a menu at base-level have a parent panel of MenuManager.menu.
        x - the string expression dictating where on the parent panel this component should go. Expressions for x-positions are commonly formatted as some variation of "centerx - width/#" in order to scale correctly.
        y - the string expression dictating where on the parent panel this component should go. Expressions for y-positions are commonly formatted as some variation of "centery - height/#" in order to scale correctly.
        See Also:
        solveString(String, int, int)

    • Method Detail

      • render

        public abstract void render​(java.awt.Graphics g,
                            int xx,
                            int yy,
                            int ww,
                            int hh)
        Draws on the graphics object to represent this component visually. When this method is called, the type of panel storing (grid or free) has been taken into account and the dimensions of the space given to this component have been calculated using solveString(String, int, int).
        Parameters:
        g - the graphics object to draw on
        xx - the x-position on the graphics image that this component's alloted space begins
        yy - the y-position on the graphics image that this component's alloted space begins
        ww - the width on the graphics image that this component is given
        hh - the height on the graphics image this component is given

      • solveString

        protected int solveString​(java.lang.String code,
                          int contWidth,
                          int contHeight)
        Determines the integer value of a coordinate based off the string code by utilizing ExpressionSolver.
        Parameters:
        code - the String to get the format from
        contWidth - the width of the container screen: used in calculations
        contHeight - the height of the container screen: used in calculations
        Returns:
        the integer value associated with the code

      • getGridLocation

        public java.awt.Point getGridLocation()
        Returns the grid location of this component if gridded.
        Returns:
        gridPoint

      • setGridLocation

        public void setGridLocation​(java.awt.Point newPoint)
        Sets the grid location of this component. If the newPoint is null, the component will think that it is not in a grid
        Parameters:
        newPoint - to replace gridPoint

      • getParent

        public Panel getParent()
        Returns the parent panel of this component.
        Returns:
        (parent

      • setParent

        public void setParent​(Panel parent)
        Sets the parent of this component, adding this to any parent lists necessary and removing it from the old parent's lists.
        Parameters:
        parent - the new parent

      • isVisible

        public boolean isVisible()
        Returns whether this component should be drawn by the parent panel during rendering.
        Returns:
        visible

      • setVisible

        public void setVisible​(boolean visibility)
        Sets the visibility of this component.
        Parameters:
        visibility - replaces the value of visible

      • setTextResizeFactor

        public static void setTextResizeFactor​(int factor)
        Sets the static text_original_size constant. Unnecessary for most components, but may be used to give more meaning or precision to text sizes for Moulton Scalable Menus.
        Parameters:
        factor - an int ratio. higher size means more precise text sizes. When the alloted height for the textual component is equal to this factor, then the font will be printed in its original (creation) size.

      • getTextVertResize

        protected int getTextVertResize​(int originalFontSize)
        When text should be resized based on the vertical size, as indicated in textResize(), most components with a textual element will resize their text font to have the size returned by this method.

        It is calculated to be in inverse proportion to text_resize_factor.

        Parameters:
        originalFontSize - the original size of the font, most commonly defined in the creation of the component
        Returns:
        the new value of the font size for this render

      • textResize

        protected boolean textResize()
        Returns:
        if text should resize by height. This is found by asking parent.

      • getRectRenderCoords

        @Deprecated
protected int[] getRectRenderCoords​(int xx,
                                    int yy,
                                    int ww,
                                    int hh,
                                    java.lang.String width,
                                    java.lang.String height)
        Deprecated.
        This has been deprecated. Please use getRenderRect(...) instead Many components are inherently rectangularly shaped, thus this method is provided to facilitate coordinate calculations of x, y, width, and height for the component. If the component is in a grid (found by checking getGridLocation()!=null, then xx, yy, ww, and hh are already useful, but if the component is in free form, then the result of solving the x and y expressions needs to be added to xx and yy.
        For rectangular components, prefixing a width or height string with a ? will indicate that the component ends there, in other words, the dimension in question is bounded by its analogous position axis (x for width, y for height) and the value of what comes after the ?. For example, if x=width/8 and width=?width, then the width of the component would result to (width-width/8).
        Parameters:
        xx - the lower x bound of the component's canvas
        yy - the lower y bound of the component's canvas
        ww - the width for the component to draw
        hh - the height for the component to draw
        width - the string expression for the component's width. Only used if the component isn't in a grid
        height - the string expression for the component's height. Only used if the component isn't in a grid
        Returns:
        a pixel array for the component of its x, y, width, and height, in that order.

      • getRenderRect

        protected java.awt.Rectangle getRenderRect​(int xx,
                                           int yy,
                                           int ww,
                                           int hh,
                                           java.lang.String width,
                                           java.lang.String height)
        Many components are inherently rectangularly shaped, thus this method is provided to facilitate coordinate calculations of x, y, width, and height for the component. If the component is in a grid (found by checking getGridLocation()!=null, then xx, yy, ww, and hh are already useful, but if the component is in free form, then the result of solving the x and y expressions needs to be added to xx and yy.
        For rectangular components, prefixing a width or height string with a ? will indicate that the component ends there, in other words, the dimension in question is bounded by its analogous position axis (x for width, y for height) and the value of what comes after the ?. For example, if x=width/8 and width=?width, then the width of the component would result to (width-width/8).
        Parameters:
        xx - the lower x bound of the component's canvas
        yy - the lower y bound of the component's canvas
        ww - the width for the component to draw
        hh - the height for the component to draw
        width - the string expression for the component's width. Only used if the component isn't in a grid
        height - the string expression for the component's height. Only used if the component isn't in a grid
        Returns:
        the rectangle for where the component should be rendered.
